div.p: I must confess my shame for my own negligence; permitting you to write me a second letter before the first was answered. Though I feel that you who has experienced the influence of K.M.I. life could not accuse another for so trivial a fault. But let me that you for your thoughtful promptness. Your fond tidings came like a zephyr bearing on its wings a balm to soothe our melancholly spirits. We had not heard a word from home since the bearings of yours of Oct 29th save a not from Martin Curry, who said that he had not heard from you since you left, and could'nt tell whether you were all dead or alive, this only increased the anxiety in which we constantly live, then Andy Wilcox wrote that Sister Rachel was very sick, of course this render our imaginations wild in the thoughts of home, and the scares of those dear ones
who aid us in cherishing its memory.

Just imagine how delighted we were to hear that Sister R was up all well and a frio crop Nous-fumes comme hors des nos-meme. I am inclined to think that your flattering remarks of my oratory and Genius had their underscorings as dashes of irony. I did not deliver my speech on "inventive genius". was allowed to hand it in on account of the number of speakers. My second, though, on "1 habit of thought". I delivered and was complimented by several on its merits. As twas my first attempts on the stage. I was much embarrased in the beginning, as I had a broad grise of the whole school to face. The cause of which was Viz. Most of the boys had spoken; Cheatham went up, handed in his oration, so did Ramsey, and of course I thought I could hand mine in too; so I handed it to Col. and started to my seat, on which Col. call to me asking if I spoke last month. I said no, and he politely said "Will Sir you must get up and read this." Of course the crowd roared, to my chaw.
